fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa} *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14543]. {panel}   If one replys to JIRA message from Outlook to JIRA configured with _NonQuotedCommentHandler_ and _CreateOrCommentHandler_ the "old" message is not striped out. The html source code for the reply message around the end of the reply and the original message looks like: {code}
Cell:966.456.452

From: James Bond (JIRA) [mailto:agent007@mi5.gov.uk]
... {code} Outlook doesn't indicate/separate the "old content" from the reply message in any way that would allow us to program JIRA to recognize and process the message. For e.g. the blue line which in this case is separating the content, can be used for other purposes too. So, we can't use it to trim the content base on it. !OutlookReply.jpg|thumbnail! For references this is a screenshot of the reply email sent from Outlook. Currently known work arounds that might work in some cases are: - Change config of each Outlook client as per [http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/outlook/HP052431761033.aspx?pid=CH063565661033]. - Stop to use this client ;) - [customise mail temples|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/dQISCw] in JIRA to include a line that will help JIRA trim messages e.g. _---- Original Message ---- _ and specify it atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/outlook-email.translations . Note, it will not trim whole message but every thing below this line and it will need to be moved to a new JIRA if you upgrade in the future.
fields.summary: Better support for reply emails from Outlook by mail handlers
Adding timeoriginalestimate field to Quick Sub-task Create form does not work as documented

fields.description:
Currently the standalone  setenv.sh has a structure like this

{code}
JAVA_OPTS="-Xms128m -Xmx256m $JAVA_OPTS -Djava.awt.headless=true -Datlassian.standalone=JIRA -Dorg.apache.jasper.runtime.BodyContentImpl.LIMIT_BUFFER=true "

# use this if you want to import data without notifications
#JAVA_OPTS=" -Datlassian.mail.senddisabled=true -Datlassian.mail.fetchdisabled=true -Datlassian.mail.popdisabled=true $JAVA_OPTS "

export JAVA_OPTS

echo "If you encounter issues starting up JIRA Standalone Edition, please see the Troubleshooting guide at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Installation+Troubleshooting+Guide"
{code}

Customers some times get it wrong when we ask them to insert certain options like GC settings and so on

Perhaps we should tweak this file to include the most common settings (commented out of course) so support can ask them to simply "uncomment" option X.  For example may something like this

{code}
#
# Change this to change the amount of mmemory that JIRA uses blah blah see hear for more info http://jira.atlasiian/memory_stuff
MEMORY_MIN="-Xms128m"
MEMORY_MAX="-Xmx256m"
#
# Un comment this option to have the JVM produce a memory should JIRA run out of memory.  This will help support work stuff out
#
#MEMORY_DUMP_OOM="-XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError"
#
#
#
# GC_LOGGING="-verbose:gc"
# GC_LOGGIN_FILE="Xloggc:gc.log"
..
.. and so on on and so on
..

JAVA_OPTS="$MEMORY_MIN $MEMORY_MAX $MEMORY_DUMP_OOM $GC_LOGGING $GC_LOGGIN_FILE -Datlassian.standalone=JIRA -Dorg.apache.jasper.runtime.BodyContentImpl.LIMIT_BUFFER=true"
{code}

This would help support by giving them more precise ways of describing what options they want set on (eg they can say to the customer uncomment MEMORY_DUMP_ON_OOM please?) and also
to more clearly explain all the options to customer since not every one is a Java command line whiz!

This would reduce the noise to information ratio for JIRA admins.
fields.summary: setenv.sh in standalone should be tweaked to have more pre-configured options

fields.description:
It is not possible to search for versions which contain spaces.

Let's supose for the tests that a project has a version called *1.3.2 - beta*.

I tried different queries:
* myproject ff:1.3.2 - beta
* myproject ff:"1.3.2 - beta"
* myproject "ff:1.3.2 - beta"
* "myproject ff:1.3.2 - beta"

But all of them don't work.

Be aware that this problem with spaces can happen with other queries as the support for components "c:" that you are implementing for the next versions.

Cheers,
Thiago
fields.summary: Smart querying: Impossible to search versions with spaces

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14532].
  {panel}

Give the ability to have cross-project workloads (estimate, actual and remaining) consolidation.
Example:
Project SOL is a "Enterprise Solution" project, involving several applications.
Project APP1 is a first "Application" used in this "Enterprise Solution".
Project APP2 is a second "Application" used in this "Enterprise Solution".

APP1 and APP2 need their own projects to manage their own issues, components and releases.
SOL needs its own project to manage Solution Requirements and any other Solution-level issue.

When a requirement is created in SOL, we would like to be able to link involved software change in APP1 and APP2 (already works fine with issue links) and consolidate workloads at the Solution requirement level.

This feature now exists when the linked issue is a sub-task. Workload is actually consolidated at the main task level and included in the workload progress bars.

We would like to have the same behavious for cross-project issues.

Linked issues' sub-tasks workloads should be included in the total.

This could be done by adding a "consolidate workload" attribute (boolean) at the issue link level, and then use this attribute to determine which issues to sum when calculating the workloads consolidation.

Pay attention to avoid endless loop.
Pay attention to count an issue workload once only.
Jira is not an accounting tool, don't bother with duplicate counting when an issue is linked to several parent issues, just count it once per parent.

Possible improvement: bother with the "several parent issues" double counting and add a second attribute "consolidation percentage" at the issue link level.
fields.summary: Cross-project issues' workload consolidation

fields.description:
It would be quite beneficial to have the help icon displayed to the right of the Components selection box when creating or editing an issue.  No matter how carefully you try to create and name your components so that the choices are intuitive, there will ultimately be confusion from users about what component to select.  When you click on the help icon it would display a list of all the components, plus the description that was added when the component was created in the project.  The additional text should minimize the chance that users create an issue with an incorrect component.

For example, when I created this issue I had to choose from the 52 possible component choices in the JIRA project.  I looked for a component named 'Help', but didn't find one, so the most likely choices were 'Documentation' and 'UI/Usability'.  I assumed that Documentation meant documentation on the Atlassian site and not on-line help, so I picked 'UI/Usability'.  However, if I could have seen the description of each component, it would have been more clear which component to select.  

The same would definitely be true for component structures created by my company.  There are often a couple of choices that seem plausible for component and being able to read the description would help.
fields.summary: Add help icon to Components selection box

fields.description:
If one wants to edit current configuration of a CVS module from Admin -> CVS Modules -> edit on submit update of log from repository is triggered.

It doesn't make sense as we should only verify if the entered info is correct  and save the changes (similarly to the _Test_ option).

Alternatively, we should re-order the process to first save the changes and than try to update as for slow connection or big repository webserver session can timeout before the update operation is completed. That makes impossible to modify / edit the CVS module and force to perform any changes directly on the database level.

fields.description:
Currently when a SOAP request comes into JIRA it lands on the AXIS servlet.

/jira/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2

This is because its a POST and not a GET.

What this means is that it hard to tell what "service method" was being invoked.

From a support point of view, you cant tell what "SOAP method" is taking a long time compared to some other SOAP method or how often one method versus another is being invoked.

JIRA needs a better way to display this information.

Perhaps a second log could be added for SOAP requests.  Perhaps a setting to cause this to go to the main log could be added.

We would at least need the "method" being invoked, so support can better work out what is going on
fields.summary: JIRA Soap Service log and Access filter log  footprint needs improving - Invoked Method would be handy

fields.description:
Can we please bring [this|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Setting+up+JIRA+Standalone+and+PostgreSQL+on+Linux#SettingupJIRAStandaloneandPostgreSQLonLinux-Creatingajirasystemaccount] point into the main JIRA installation documentation trunk. Maybe insert it [here|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/requirements.html], at Point 2. ?

specifically: 
{noformat}
Creating a jira system account

As JIRA runs as the user it is invoked under, and therefore can potentially be abused, it is a good idea to create a dedicated user to run JIRA. For example under linux:

$ sudo /usr/sbin/useradd --create-home --home-dir /usr/local/jira --shell /bin/bash jira
{noformat}
fields.summary: recommend that the default user which invokes JIRA not be a system account such as root

fields.description:
When there are HTML tags in the Jelly input, for example in an issue description, these tags will be interpreted in the errordump.

It can break the display and also prevent the developer from reading the error message.

Please convert special characters into html entities to avoid these problems. 

Thanks :)

Nicolas.

[EDIT] :
I triggered this bug a while ago, so I had troubles reproducing it.

This sample will raise it :

{code:xml}
<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.JiraTagLib">
<jira:CreateIssue description="

<form method='post' action='&'>

<input type='text' size='150'/>

</form>

" issueType="Bug" priority="Major" project-key="PYWP" summary="sum" />
</JiraJelly>
{code}

This one is tricky : If you remove &amp; from the action, the code will get parsed correctly

I will provide other code examples, if you need so.
fields.summary: Failed Jelly Run does not escape HTML from the Jelly INPUT

fields.description:

{noformat}
setup.errors.locale.build.incompatible=The default language configured in the import data is not available in this installation of JIRA. Please contact Atlassian for further details.
{noformat}

It seams that it was meant to be used be *SetupImport* action.

It could be useful to log a message if such would help support. Some similar message could be also displayed to the user. Although importing data of a non-installed language will not affect JIRA (it'll simply fall back to it's default language), it could be useful to let the person performing the import know that this is the case.

I will leave this message key in the file and put a comment next to it linking it to this issue.
fields.summary: Add a log message if the user imports data with locale not installed in JIRA

fields.description:
In the JIRA Standard Edition.

1. Enable Issue Linking

2. Create a set of link types, "duplicates" and "requires" say...

3. Create a Link between two issues

At this there is no option to manage the issue link; so to change the link type from "duplicates" to "requires" it is necessary to delete and re-create the link...

fields.description:
When stopping tomcat wich hosts only Jira, there is always such stack trace in tomcat logs:

{code}
2008-02-18 19:25:32,767: [ERROR] [Thread-33] - org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[localhost].[/jira].release() - ApplicationFilterConfig.doAsPrivilege
java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.IllegalAccessException
	at org.apache.catalina.security.SecurityUtil.execute(SecurityUtil.java:277)
	at org.apache.catalina.security.SecurityUtil.doAsPrivilege(SecurityUtil.java:217)
	at org.apache.catalina.security.SecurityUtil.doAsPrivilege(SecurityUtil.java:177)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterConfig.release(ApplicationFilterConfig.java:249)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.filterStop(StandardContext.java:3669)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.stop(StandardContext.java:4349)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.removeChild(ContainerBase.java:892)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.undeployApps(HostConfig.java:1164)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.stop(HostConfig.java:1135)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.lifecycleEvent(HostConfig.java:312)
	at org.apache.catalina.util.LifecycleSupport.fireLifecycleEvent(LifecycleSupport.java:119)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.stop(ContainerBase.java:1054)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.stop(ContainerBase.java:1066)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardEngine.stop(StandardEngine.java:447)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardService.stop(StandardService.java:512)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardServer.stop(StandardServer.java:743)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Catalina.stop(Catalina.java:601)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Catalina$CatalinaShutdownHook.run(Catalina.java:644)
{code}

These errors occur only after turning on log4j logging on tomcat instead of standard logging. The procedure is described here:

http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/logging.html

As we are sending error logs of tomcat to our system administrator's mail, we also had to remove all javamail related libraries from jira webapp, and put them in {{$TOMCAT_HOME/common/lib}} directory.

Remote debug of this tomcat instance shows such error as a cause of the above stack trace:

{code}
Class org.apache.catalina.security.SecurityUtil$1 can not access a member of class com.atlassian.gzipfilter.AbstractFilter with modifiers "public" 
{code}

In the HTML version of the same email, the author of the comment is labeled as "Unassigned" instead of "Anonymous". Should this also be changed?

fields.description:
When JIRA is used:
 - with GZip compression enabled (not the default)
 - behind Apache configured with mod_proxy_ajp (and probably mod_jk)
 - with Apache delivering pages over SSL (https)

then viewing an issue the first time will work fine, but refreshing (ctrl+r) the page will cause it to hang for 30s, before displaying the issue with a broken CSS stylesheet:

!jira_nostylesheet.png|thumbnail!

This is consistently repeatable in Mozilla 1.7. It is sometimes repeatable in Firefox (2.x). We have not heard of the problem affecting Safari or IE.
fields.summary: When viewing issues, JIRA hangs for 30s, then renders page without stylesheets when using GZip compression, mod_jk / mod_proxy_ajp and SSL

fields.description:
Our #1 complaint here is that too many emails are received when a request is received and pushed through the workflow to closure quickly.  We however, do not want to give the developer the ability to go right from open to close, else they would rarely use the Start and Stop progress, along with a couple more custom steps we've added.  

Reporters, in many cases, receive 4 status updates within 1 minute, and Outlook doesn't order them chronologically, but by subject. 

A solution for this is that some logic could be added to the email engine to only send the last status update for each unique issue within 1 minute or some selectable #.
fields.summary: Need ability to surpress multiple notifications on same issue within # minutes
Add "&os_authType=basic" to the RSS feeds links in JIRA by default

fields.description:
While working with issue, it may be useful to ask for review in a kind of 'for your information' manner, meaning you don't want to reassign the ticket.

It would be nice to have 'Ask Review' or 'Notify' action where you specify a person (ajaxed field) and some message like 'Take a look at my current solution and let me know if any concerns' and then click Send. As a result email is sent to the person containing back link to the issue, name of message author and message itself.

This way ticket is still being assigned to you and continue working on it, but you send some personal email to your colleague/manager about it. Such message is easier to distinguish from *lots* of notification coming to you as from other jira workflow operations.
fields.summary: Notify action

fields.description:
If Integrity checker is run over data with a duplicated entries for a single subscription, the tool reports this issue and offers to repair the problem.
{noformat}
Check for invalid filter subscriptions

    * PASSED: Check FilterSubscriptions for references to non-existent QuartzTriggers
    * PASSED: Check FilterSubscriptions for references to non-existent SearchRequests

Check for existance of SimpleTriggers
ERROR: SimpleTrigger with name SUBSCRIPTION_10033 is missing its corresponding filter subscription and will be removed.
{noformat}

Although, if one tries to fix it using the Fix button, Jira crashes with "java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Passed List had more than one value" and in the log file is recoded:
{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Passed List had more than one value.
	at org.ofbiz.core.entity.EntityUtil.getOnly(EntityUtil.java:58)
	at com.atlassian.scheduler.OfBizJobStore.removeTrigger(OfBizJobStore.java:332)
	at org.quartz.core.QuartzScheduler.unscheduleJob(QuartzScheduler.java:680)
	at org.quartz.impl.StdScheduler.unscheduleJob(StdScheduler.java:268)

{noformat}
fields.summary: Integrity checker shouldn't offer repairs, if duplicated subscriptions are discovered.

fields.description:
In the documentations regarding setting up JIRA on Tomcat on the following pages:
- for Tomcat 5.5 at http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/tomcat55.html
- for 6.x at http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/tomcat60.html

We give example of connecting JIRA to a MySQL database.
{code:xml}
<Context path="/jira" docBase="path/to/atlassian-jira-3.12.2.war">
  <Resource name="jdbc/JiraDS" auth="Container" type="javax.sql.DataSource"
    username="jirauser"
    password="mypassword"
    driverClassName="com.mysql.jdbc.Driver"
    url="jdbc:mysql://localhost/jiradb?autoReconnect=true"/>
  <Resource name="UserTransaction" auth="Container" type="javax.transaction.UserTransaction"
    factory="org.objectweb.jotm.UserTransactionFactory"
    jotm.timeout="60"/>
  <Manager pathname=""/>
</Context>
{code}
the URL parameter should be constructed
{code:xml}
url="jdbc:mysql://localhost/jiradb?autoReconnect=true&useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF8"
{code}
There is a significant number of the cases in SAC where customers have problems with encoding if the character encoding is not specified in the URL. Additionally, it would keep our documentation consistent across all pages referring to Mysql; e.g. http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/databases/mysql.html

Basically, people don't intend to navigate to the MySQL configuration page since we provide the example on the Tomcat integration pages.
fields.summary: Improvement on Tomcat 6.x, 5.5 documents

fields.description:
We get more support requests than we ought to from customers who want to export the XML of a workflow, however they have problems because they do it by:
# clicking on the XML link in Internet Explorer
# IE displays the XML, however it puts extra "-" characters in the XML
# the user then copies the XML and saves it to a file, however it also contains the extra "-" characters
# the import fails because of the extra "-" characters

Could we modify the user interface to make it harder for a user to have this problem?

A few possible solutions:

1. Change the XML link to do the same as Backup Data to XML works. That is, prompt the user for a file location, and save the file there for them. This has these disadvantages:
- the user will need System Administrator privilege, not just Administrator, because they will have to access the server file system
- the file can only be saved to the server, not to the client computer

2. Change the text of the link from "XML" to something like "XML (right click and save to file)". Might help, but I suspect it will just confuse some users.

3. When they click on the XML link, take them to another screen which shows the XML in a text field. This gets around IE seeing the XML MIME type and displaying it. In the same page, under the text field, have a link to download the XML, and have text saying to right click on the link and save it to a file. This way the user can either safely copy and paste the XML, or save the XML directly to a file.

I like option 3 best, but I'm open to alternative suggestions.

Note that simply changing the MIME type of the workflow XML to something other than XML in order to "fool" IE is probably not an option, as Chris assures me that IE ignores this and displays it as XML anyway, in the same way as if you change your viewer for the XML MIME type to be something other than IE, IE ignores you and displays any XML anyway.
fields.summary: Make exporting workflow XML avoid displaying the XML in Internet Explorer

fields.description:
We get more support requests than we ought to from customers who are doing a CSV import and getting a "CSV file does not exist error" because their CSV file is on their client PC instead of on the server running JIRA.

I can see how this happens, since the user has probably be working with the file in Excel to massage its format and data. They are likely to do this on their PC, rather than on the server, because (for example):
- they don't have Excel running on the server running JIRA
- they got emailed it by someone else, and they read their email from their PC

They then don't think to copy it over to the server.

Can we please enhance the CSV import feature so that it works with a file on the client? That is, automagically upload the CSV file from the client to the server running JIRA.

I guess we could add a warning to the text message in the CSV Import Wizard, but my gut feel is that a better solution is to actually fix the problem.
fields.summary: Allow CSV file for CSV Import to be on the user's client machine

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14442].
  {panel}

Scenario:
1. In browser's window (call it "Tab1") create a search to Find some issues....  - OR - open a saved filter.  (call this result "Filter1")
2. Do some important manipulation of Filter1, such as sort by Assignee.
3. Decide that then you want to cross reference another filter, or search for another specific issue, thus:
4. Open a new browser window/tab (call it "Tab2").   Run another search... - OR - open a different saved filter.  (call this result "Filter2")
5. Return to Tab1's original search results (Filter1) and attempt to manipulate it further, such as sort by a column, or click to next search result page.
6. Observe:  The resulting display in Tab1 executes against Filter2.  Your view of Filter1 is irretreviably lost.

Thus you can only ever engage with one 'active' filter in a browser session.  Using 2+ filters simultaneously (even if Saved Filters) are not supported.  

We cull so frequently and complexly from the data in our jira project, that this is a huge drawback.
fields.summary: Support more than one 'active'/simultaneous Issue filter in a session

fields.description:
In 3.11 the labels plugin changed so that manipulating labels required the "Edit Issue" permission.  This drastically impacted our organizations workflow, as we'd just introduced labels in our previous upgrade, and we don't give "edit issues" to all users, but we do want all authenticated users to be able to manipulate lables.

As a compromise from LBL-73 we suggest adding an "Edit Labels" permission, similar to the attachments/comments permission scheme.  This would allow customers to choose between the old label behavior (reported as too permissive in LBL-73) and the new label behavior (too restrictive for our use).

We've also opened support JSP-19701 originally listing this as a bug/support case.

Thanks!

-Scott
fields.summary: Seperate label permissions from edit issue permission

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14424].
  {panel}

The "Browse projects" permission mixes up two different things: (1) permission to see a project at all, (2) permission to see project issues. These two capabilities should have distinct permissions. The current mixup drastically reduces the usefulness of granting permissions to "Reporter" and "Current assignee". A distinct "View project" permission should be required before any other permission is considered. The current "Browse projects" permission could be renamed to "Browse issues".

Currently if you grant "Browse project" to "Reporter", ALL users can see ALL projects, even those where they have no role. Of course you can create a permission scheme per project, but that nullifies the whole point of having permission schemes.

This subject has been extensively discussed previously (JRA-4093, JRA-4935, JRA-8950, JRA-11881, JRA-14307). A fix is identified in JRA-14307. It's great to have a patch, but much better to solve the underlying problem.


*Workaround* 
This might help in some cases : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Current+Reporter+Browse+Project+Permission.
fields.summary: Separate permissions for issue filtering and project display

fields.description:
Establishing the initial trusted app connection requires the user to enter a URL which should be the base URL of another application which would then become a trusted client. The following case uses Confluence as an example of the trusted client and JIRA as the service provider, as with the JIRA issues macro.

The problem with the input is that there are several classes of error that are not nicely handled or reported.

* The user may mistakenly supply os_username and os_password parameters which wrecks the request for the trusted application certificate. The result is that the remote application will return a "login incorrect" page which is attempted to be parsed as a certificate and the one line error suggests the certificate format is unsupported.
* URLs are required to not have any query parameters because the input url is appended with a path to the certificate request action.
* The base URL could be validated by a request to it and looking for an atlassian footer or something.
* RuntimeException is not caught by the ViewTrustedApplications action and can result in a 500 page. There is a [Linux JDK 1.6|http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6520665] bug that can occur in cases of authorization challenge responses (401) and can happen if the Confluence instance has the [NTLM plugin|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFEXT/NTLM+Authenticator+for+Confluence] installed.

Seraph should also have its certificate request protocol improved to enable detection of responses that are not supposed to be certificates.

See also SER-109
fields.summary: Trusted Apps Initial Request Phase: Detect and report obvious classes of user input errors.

When I init a move of Issue IA from projet A to Project B, the Wizard ask :

fields.description:
Trying to use the trusted authentication feature of the Jiraissues macro doesn't work when a user's username is uppercase. JIRA shows the following in its log:

{quote}
2008-01-23 13:59:48,104 INFO [STDOUT] 2008-01-23 13:59:48,104 ajp-0.0.0.0-6103-8 WARN [atlassian.seraph.filter.TrustedApplicationsFilter] User 'BOB' referenced by trusted application: 'confluence:7521898' is not found.
{quote}

To reproduce:

1. Have an LDAP repository with a username with uppercase letters, BOB. The LDAP server should do case-insensitive authentication, like in Active Directory.
2. Connect Confluence and JIRA to the LDAP repository. JIRA for authentication only via OSUser, Confluence via Atlassian-User.
3. Set up a local user for 'bob' in JIRA, which must be lowercase because all JIRA usernames must be lowercase.
4. Log in to Confluence as 'bob' (or 'BOB', it doesn't matter). Confluence creates the user as 'BOB', because it respects the case of the underlying system.
5. Use an authenticated {jiraissues} macro to retrieve issues from JIRA as 'BOB'.
6. The above error message appears in the JIRA log, which can't authenticate 'BOB'.

Note that the most common case for installations using trusted authentication is with an external user repository like LDAP, so this is a serious problem for the trusted authentication feature.
fields.summary: Trusted authentication doesn't work for Confluence users with uppercase usernames

fields.description: ManagerFactory.globalRefresh() will recreate the TrustedApplicationsManager singleton, but the filter has a final reference to the old manager. This needs to resolved at run-time.
fields.summary: TrustedApplicationFilter does not refresh TrustedApplicationsManager  dependency when data imported

fields.description:
To reproduce this issue, do the following:

# Create Project AAA
# Create Project BBB
# Create an Issue Level Security Scheme, and assign it to AAA only
# Create a Clone of the Default Field Configuration Scheme.  Hide the field *Security Level* on the Cloned copy.  Assign the Cloned copy to BBB.
# Create a New Issue in AAA
# Move the Issue to BBB

You'll notice that on the screen before you actually click MOVE, and it'll list the before and after columns.  On the before column, it will show the security level correct.  On the after column, it's blank.

This can be worked-around by Unhiding the Security Level on the Field Config Scheme.
fields.summary: Moving an issue from a project with Issue Security to a project without does not clear out the security
